factoid: Princess Mary had her father's funeral.
After the funeral, Princess Mary shut herself up in her room and did not admit anyone.
A maid came to the door to say that Alpátych was asking for orders about their departure.
The maid's message was delivered before Alpátych's talk with Dron.
Princess Mary raised herself on the sofa on which she had been lying.
Princess Mary replied through the closed door that she did not mean to go away.
Princess Mary begged to be left in peace.
The windows of Princess Mary's room looked westward.
Princess Mary lay on the sofa with her face to the wall.
Princess Mary was fingering the buttons of the leather cushion.
Princess Mary's confused thoughts were centered on the irrevocability of death.
Princess Mary's confused thoughts were also centered on her own spiritual baseness.
Princess Mary had not suspected her own spiritual baseness before.
Princess Mary's spiritual baseness had shown itself during her father's illness.
Princess Mary wished to pray but did not dare to address herself to God in her present state of mind.
Princess Mary lay for a long time in that position.
The sun had reached the other side of the house.
The slanting rays of the sun shone into the open window.
The slanting rays lit up the room and part of the Moroccan cushion at which Princess Mary was looking.
The flow of Princess Mary's thoughts suddenly stopped.
Unconsciously Princess Mary sat up.
Princess Mary smoothed her hair.
Princess Mary got up.
Princess Mary went to the window.
Princess Mary inhaled the freshness of the clear but windy evening.
Princess Mary said to herself, "Yes, you can well enjoy the evening now! He is gone and no one will hinder you."
Princess Mary sank into a chair.
Princess Mary let her head fall on the window sill.
Someone spoke Princess Mary's name in a soft and tender voice from the garden.
Someone kissed Princess Mary's head.
The person was Mademoiselle Bourienne in a black dress and weepers.
Mademoiselle Bourienne softly approached Princess Mary.
Mademoiselle Bourienne sighed.
Mademoiselle Bourienne kissed Princess Mary.
Mademoiselle Bourienne immediately began to cry.
Princess Mary looked up at Mademoiselle Bourienne.
All former disharmony and Princess Mary's jealousy recurred to Princess Mary's mind.
Princess Mary remembered that Alpátych had changed of late toward Mademoiselle Bourienne.
Princess Mary could not bear to see Mademoiselle Bourienne.
Princess Mary's reproaches toward Mademoiselle Bourienne were unjust.
Princess Mary thought, "Besides, is it for me, for me who desired his death, to condemn anyone?"
Princess Mary vividly pictured the position of Mademoiselle Bourienne.
Princess Mary had of late kept Mademoiselle Bourienne at a distance.
Mademoiselle Bourienne was dependent on Princess Mary.
Mademoiselle Bourienne lived in Princess Mary's house.
Princess Mary felt sorry for Mademoiselle Bourienne.
Princess Mary held out her hand with a glance of gentle inquiry.
Mademoiselle Bourienne began crying again.
Mademoiselle Bourienne kissed Princess Mary's hand.
Mademoiselle Bourienne spoke of Princess Mary's sorrow.
Mademoiselle Bourienne made herself a partner in Princess Mary's sorrow.
Mademoiselle Bourienne said her only consolation was that Princess Mary allowed her to share her sorrow.
Mademoiselle Bourienne said all old misunderstandings should sink into nothing but great grief.
Mademoiselle Bourienne said she felt herself blameless in regard to everyone.
Mademoiselle Bourienne said he, from above, saw her affection and gratitude.
Princess Mary heard Mademoiselle Bourienne.
Princess Mary occasionally looked up at Mademoiselle Bourienne and listened to the sound of her voice.
Mademoiselle Bourienne said, "Your position is doubly terrible, dear princess."
Mademoiselle Bourienne said she understood that Princess Mary could not, and cannot, think of herself.
Mademoiselle Bourienne said with her love for Princess Mary she must do so.
Mademoiselle Bourienne asked, "Has Alpátych been to you?"
Mademoiselle Bourienne asked, "Has he spoken to you of going away?"
Princess Mary did not answer.
Princess Mary did not understand who was to go or where to.
Princess Mary thought, "Is it possible to plan or think of anything now? Is it not all the same?"
Princess Mary did not reply.

Mademoiselle Bourienne said, "You know, chère Marie, that we are in danger—are surrounded by the French. It would be dangerous to move now. If we go we are almost sure to be taken prisoners, and God knows..."
Princess Mary looked at Mademoiselle Bourienne without understanding what she was talking about.
Princess Mary said, "Oh, if anyone knew how little anything matters to me now."
Princess Mary said, "Of course I would on no account wish to go away from him. Alpátych did say something about going. Speak to him; I can do nothing, nothing, and don’t want to."
Mademoiselle Bourienne said, "I’ve spoken to him. He hopes we should be in time to get away tomorrow, but I think it would now be better to stay here."
Mademoiselle Bourienne said, "Because, you will agree, chère Marie, to fall into the hands of the soldiers or of riot peasants would be terrible."
